tit.e: The Reizei family
The Reizei family
The Reizei family

sen.j: 冷泉家（れいぜいけ）は公家の一。
sen.e: The Reizei family is one of the court nobilities.
The Reizei family belonged to the court nobility.
The Reizei family belonged to the court nobility.

sen.j: 近衛中将に代々任命された羽林家とよばれる武官の家柄の公家。
sen.e: The family is the court nobility of the house standing of military officer called Urin family which had been appointed to a Konoe Chujo, Lieutenant General of Imperial Guard.
The family was an Urin family, which meant having the status of military officers at court, and would supply Konoe Chujo, the Lieutenant Generals of the Imperial Guard.
The family was an Urin family, which meant having the status of military officers at court, and would supply Konoe Chujo, the Lieutenant Generals of the Imperial Guard.

sen.j: 藤原北家。
sen.e: the House of Fujiwara North
the House of Fujiwara North
the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan

tit.e: Brief overview
Summary
tit.cmt: This is translated as "summary" in the reference files.
tit.e: Summary

sen.j: 藤原道長の子藤原長家を祖とする御子左流二条派（五摂家の二条家とは別）の庶流。
sen.e: The branch family of Nijo branch of Mikosa line (it is different from Nijo family of the Five Sekke (Regent) family), which ancestor is FUJIWARA no Nagaie, who was the son of FUJIWARA no Michinaga.

The Reizei family is a sideline of the Nijo branch of the Mikosa line descended from FUJIWARA no Nagaie, the son of FUJIWARA no Michinaga (not to be confused with the Nijo branch of the Five Sekke (Regent) family).
sen.cmt: Not sure about this, but it looks like the Reizei family is the subject here.
sen.e: The Reizei family is a sideline of the Nijo branch of the Mikosa line descended from FUJIWARA no Nagaie, the son of FUJIWARA no Michinaga (not to be confused with the Nijo branch of the Five Sekke (Regent) family).

sen.j: 藤原為家（藤原定家の子）の子である冷泉為相（母は『十六夜日記』で有名な阿仏尼）から始まる。
sen.e: The family started from Tamesuke REIZEI (whose mother was Abutsuni, priestess Abutsu, the author of "Izayoi Nikki"), who was the son of FUJIWARA no Tameie (the son of FUJIWARA no Sadaie).
The family originated with Tamesuke REIZEI (whose mother was Abutsuni, priestess Abutsu and the author of "Izayoi Nikki"), who was the son of FUJIWARA no Tameie (the son of FUJIWARA no Sadaie).
The family originated with Tamesuke REIZEI (whose mother was Abutsuni, priestess Abutsu and the author of "Izayoi Nikki"), who was the son of FUJIWARA no Tameie (the son of FUJIWARA no Sadaie).

sen.j: 家名は平安京の冷泉小路に由来する。
sen.e: The family name came from Reizei-koji Street, in Heian-kyo, Kyoto.
The family name derives from Reizei-koji Street, in Heian-kyo, Kyoto.
The family name derives from Reizei-koji Street, in Heian-kyo, Kyoto.

sen.j: 家業は歌道・蹴鞠。
sen.e: The family business were Kado, the waka study, and Kemari, the ancient football game in Japan.
The family businesses were Kado, the study of waka, and Kemari, the ancient Japanese football game.
The family businesses were Kado, the study of waka, and Kemari, the ancient Japanese football game.

sen.j: 歌風は、本家である二条家および京極派（武家の京極氏とは別）に比べるならば、そう特徴的なものはない。
sen.e: Its style of waka is not much distinctive compared to that of Nijo family, the main house, or Kyogoku school (different form the Kyogoku family of bushi).
The family's style of waka does not stand out next to that of the Nijo family, the main house, or the Kyogoku school (different from the Kyogoku family of bushi).
The family's style of waka does not stand out next to that of the Nijo family, the main house, or the Kyogoku school (different from the Kyogoku family of bushi).

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)中期に上冷泉家（かみれいぜいけ）・下冷泉家（しもれいぜいけ）の2家に分かれた。
sen.e: The family fell into two families, the Kami Reizei family and the Shimo Reizei family, in the middle of the South and North Courts Period (of Japan).
The family split into two, the Kami Reizei family and the Shimo Reizei family, midway through the South and North Courts Period (of Japan).
The family split into two, the Kami Reizei family and the Shimo Reizei family, midway through the Northern and Southern Courts Period (of Japan).
sen.cmt: 「南北朝時代」の表記を統一しました。

sen.j: 両家とも現在に続く名門であるが、一般に冷泉家として知られるのは、江戸時代から屋敷が移転していない上冷泉家のほうである。
sen.e: Both of them are the families of pedigree which have existed to today, and the family publicly known as the Reizei family is the Kami Reizei family, which residence has not been relocated since the Edo Period.
Both of these distinguished families still exist today, the family now known as the Reizei family being the Kami Reizei family, whose residence has not been relocated since the Edo Period.
Both of these distinguished families still exist today, the family now known as the Reizei family being the Kami Reizei family, whose residence has not been relocated since the Edo Period.

sen.j: 下冷泉家の屋敷は、京都御苑内に位置していたため、公家町を公園として整備するさい取り壊された。
sen.e: Because the residence of the Shimo Reizei family was located inside Kyoto Imperial Park, the mansion was demolished when the town of court nobilities was developed to a park.
Because the residence of the Shimo Reizei family was located within Kyoto Gyoen, it was demolished when the town of the court nobility was made into a park.
sen.cmt: I don't like "town of court nobilities" as the translation for 公家町. "Town of the court nobility" is better.
sen.e: Because the residence of the Shimo Reizei family was located within Kyoto Gyoen (Kyoto Imperial Park), it was demolished when the town of the court nobility was made into a park.
sen.cmt: 京都御苑=Kyoto Gyoen (Kyoto Imperial Park) としました。

sen.j: 上冷泉家の江戸時代における家格は羽林家で、官位は概ね権大納言民部卿を極官とした。
sen.e: The family status of the Kami Reizei family in the Edo Period was the Urin family, and their final official rank was basically Gon-no-Dainagon Mimbu-kyo, Junior Chief of the Councillor of State and Director of Popular Affairs Office.

The Kami Reizei family had Urin family status in the Edo period, eventually reaching an official rank of Gon-no-Dainagon Mimbu-kyo, Junior Chief of the Councilor of State and Director of Popular Affairs Office.

The Kami Reizei family had Urin family status in the Edo period, eventually reaching an official rank of Gon-no-Dainagon Mimbu-kyo, Junior Chief of the Councilor of State and Director of Popular Affairs Office.

tit.e: Its early period to the end of the Kamakura Period
Early period to the end of the Kamakura Period
tit.cmt: Not sure what the "it" is referring to here. If "it" is the family, I think the sentence can do without.
tit.e: Early period to the end of the Kamakura Period

sen.j: 冷泉為相は鎌倉幕府と親しく、長らく鎌倉の藤ヶ谷に居を構え藤谷黄門と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Tamesuke REIZEI was close to the Kamakura Shogunate and called Fujigaya Komon, setting up its home at Fujigayatsu in Kamakura for a long time.
Tamesuke REIZEI was close to the Kamakura Shogunate and came be known as Fujigaya Komon for setting up a long-term home at Fujigayatsu in Kamakura.
Tamesuke REIZEI was close to the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and came to be known as Fujigaya Komon for setting up a long-term home at Fujigayatsu in Kamakura.
sen.cmt: 幕府の表現を変更しました。「to」を追加。

sen.j: 娘の一人は鎌倉将軍の久明親王（持明院統の後深草天皇の皇子）に嫁ぎ、外孫の久良親王が誕生している。
sen.e: One of his daughters married into Imperial Prince Hisaaki of the Kamakura Shogunate (the prince of Emperor Gofukakusa of the Jimyoin line), and Imperial Prince Hisayoshi, the grandson on mother's side, was born.
One of his daughters married Imperial Prince Hisaaki of the Kamakura Shogunate (the son of Emperor Gofukakusa of the Jimyoin line) and gave birth to Imperial Prince Hisayoshi.
One of his daughters married Imperial Prince Hisaaki of the Kamakura bakufu (the son of the Emperor Gofukakusa of the Jimyoin line) and gave birth to Imperial Prince Hisayoshi.
sen.cmt: 幕府＝bakufu"the" を挿入しました。

tit.j: 南北朝時代～江戸時代の下冷泉家
tit.e: The Shimo Reizei family from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts to the Edo Period
The Shimo Reizei family from the Northern and Southern Courts Period to the Edo Period
The Shimo Reizei family from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts to the Edo Period

sen.j: 南北朝時代、冷泉為尹の長男冷泉為之の上冷泉家と、次男冷泉持為の下冷泉家に分かれた。
sen.e: In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the family fell into two families, the Kami Reizei family of Tameyuki REIZEI, the first son of Tamehiro REIZEI, and the Shimo Reizei family of Mochitame REIZEI, the second son of Temehiro REIZEI.

In the Northern and Southern Courts Period, the family split into two families, the Kami Reizei family of Tameyuki REIZEI, the first son of Tamehiro REIZEI, and the Shimo Reizei family of Mochitame REIZEI, the second son of Temehiro REIZEI.

In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the family split into two families, the Kami Reizei family of Tameyuki REIZEI, the first son of Tamehiro REIZEI, and the Shimo Reizei family of Mochitame REIZEI, the second son of Temehiro REIZEI.

sen.j: 持為は、冷泉家の当主にはならなかったが、その実力を足利氏から認められ、独立した一家をもうけることが許され、兄の冷泉家とは別に同じ冷泉家を名乗ることも許された。
sen.e: Not taking up the family head of the Reizei family, though, Mochitame was recognized his ability by the Ashikaga clan, and permitted to set up an independent family and use the same name of Reizei family separately from his brother's Reizei family.

Although Mochitame was not by right the head of the family, his ability was recognized by the Ashikaga clan and he was permitted set up an independent family, separate from the Reizei family headed by his elder brother, but under the same Reizei name.

Although Mochitame was not by right the head of the family, his ability was recognized by the Ashikaga clan and he was permitted to set up an independent family, separate from the Reizei family headed by his elder brother, but under the same Reizei name.

sen.j: 所領及び家に伝わる文書は、この時二分された。
sen.e: The territory of the family and documents passed down in the family were divided in half this time.
The family land and documents were divided in half this time.
sen.cmt: This is a slight simplification, but I think the meaning is fairly clear.
sen.e: The family land and documents were divided in half on this occasion.

sen.j: 『十六夜日記』で有名な細川庄は、下冷泉家の相続分である。
sen.e: The Hosokawa estate known for "Izayoi Nikki" was the share in succession of the Shimo Reizei family.
The Hosokawa estate made famous in "Izayoi Nikki" passed to the Shimo Reizei family.
The Hosokawa estate made famous in "Izayoi Nikki" passed to the Shimo Reizei family.

sen.j: 下冷泉持為・下冷泉政為は、それぞれ将軍足利義持・足利義政に厚遇され、偏諱まで賜った。
sen.e: Mochitame and Masatame SHIMO REIZEI were treated well by the Shogunate Yoshimochi and Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA respectively, and even received one character from their names.
Mochitame and Masatame SHIMO REIZEI were treated well by the Yoshimochi and Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA Shogunates, and were even granted the use of a character from the Shoguns' names.
Mochitame and Masatame SHIMO REIZEI were treated well by the Yoshimochi and Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA Shogunates, and were even granted the use of a character from the Shoguns' names.

sen.j: この時期は、下冷泉家こそ冷泉家の本流であった。
sen.e: In this period, it was the Shimo Reizei family that was the main stream of the Reizei family.
In this period, it was the Shimo Reizei family that was the main line of the Reizei family.
In this period, it was the Shimo Reizei family that was the main line of the Reizei family.

sen.j: 戦国時代は、大名による横領を防ぐため、先述の播磨国細川庄に下向していた。
sen.e: In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), the family went down to the Hosokawa estate in the Province of Harima, which was noted previously, to prevent embezzlement by feudal lords.
In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), the family moved away to the above-mentioned Hosokawa estate in the Province of Harima to prevent it being taken over by feudal lords.
In the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), the family moved away to the above-mentioned Hosokawa estate in Harima Province to prevent it being taken over by feudal lords.

sen.j: ところが、冷泉為純 下冷泉為勝が播磨守護大名赤松氏の支族別所氏に殺されたため、為勝の弟の下冷泉為将が京都において下冷泉家を再興した。
sen.e: However, because Tamezumi REIZEI and Tamekatsu SHIMOREIZEI were killed by the Bessho clan, who was the Shugo (Military Govenor) Daimyo of the Akamatsu clan of the Province of Harima, Tamemasa SHIMOREIZEI, the younger brother of Tamekatsu, rebuilt the Shimo Reizei family in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 「冷泉為純 下冷泉為勝」とありますが、「冷泉」か「下冷泉」どちらかにそろっているはずではないかと思います。
sen.e: However, Tamezumi REIZEI and Tamekatsu SHIMO REIZEI were killed by the Bessho clan, who were the Shugo (Military Governor) Daimyo of the Akamatsu clan of the Province of Harima, and this led Tamemasa SHIMO REIZEI, Tamekatsu's the younger brother, to rebuild the Shimo Reizei family in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: I agree with comment in column E. I think Shimo Reizai is better.
sen.e: However, Tamezumi REIZEI and Tamekatsu SHIMO REIZEI were killed by the Bessho clan, who were the Shugo (Military Governor) Daimyo of the Akamatsu clan of Harima Province, and this led Tamemasa SHIMO REIZEI, Tamekatsu's the younger brother, to rebuild the Shimo Reizei family in Kyoto.

sen.j: 日本儒学の祖とされる冷泉粛（朱子学者藤原惺窩として有名）は下冷泉為将の兄である。
sen.e: Shuku REIZEI, who was the patriarch of Japanese Confucian (known as Seika FUJIWARA, the neo-Confucianist), was the elder brother of Tamemasa SHIMO REIZEI.
Shuku REIZEI, the patriarch of Japanese Confucianism (and famous as Seika FUJIWARA, the neo-Confucianist), was Tamemasa SHIMO REIZEI's elder brother.
sen.cmt: 日本儒学の祖→the patriarch of Japanese Confucianism
sen.e: Shuku REIZEI, the patriarch of Japanese Confucianism (and famous as Seika FUJIWARA, the neo-Confucianist), was Tamemasa SHIMO REIZEI's elder brother.

sen.j: 彼自身は下冷泉家の当主になる機会はなかったが、息子の冷泉為景が為将の養子として当主になり、その血統が子孫に続いている。
sen.e: He had no chance to be the head of the Shimo Reizei family, however, his son, Tamekage REIZEI, became the family head as a adopted son of Tamemasa, and his blood line continues to the descendant.

While Shuku REIZEI did not have the opportunity to head the Shimo Reizei family himself, his son, Tamekage REIZEI, was adopted by Tememasa and went on to head the Reizei family and continue the bloodline.

While Shuku REIZEI did not have the opportunity to head the Shimo Reizei family himself, his son, Tamekage REIZEI, was adopted by Tememasa and went on to head the Reizei family and continue the bloodline.

sen.j: 下冷泉家は播磨下向時代以来豊臣秀吉と親しい間柄だったため、秀吉は下冷泉家の再興に協力を惜しまなかった。
sen.e: The Shimo Reizei family had had a close relationship with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI since the period it went down to Harima so that Hideyoshi cooperated fully to restore the Shimo Reizei family.
The Shimo Reizei family had maintained a close relationship with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI from their time in Harima, and Hideyoshi actively cooperated in restoring their fortunes.
The Shimo Reizei family had maintained a close relationship with Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI from their time in Harima, and Hideyoshi actively cooperated in restoring their fortunes.

tit.j: 南北朝時代～江戸時代の上冷泉家
tit.e: The Kami Reizei family from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts Period to the Edo Period
The Kami Reizei family from the Northern and Southern Courts Period to the Edo Period
The Kami Reizei family from the Northern and Southern Courts Period to the Edo Period

sen.j: 上冷泉家も戦国時代 (日本)は、能登守護畠山氏や駿河守護今川氏を頼り地方に下向しており、都にはいなかった。
sen.e: Because the Kami Reizei family also went down to local areas depending on the Hatakeyama family, Military Governor of Noto and the Imagawa family, Military Governor of Suruga in the period of Warring States (Japan), they were not in the capital.

The Kami Reizei family were also out of the capital in the period of the Warring States (Japan), moving to the provinces and into the care of the Hatakeyama family, the Military Governors of Noto, and the Imagawa family, the Military Governors of Suruga.

The Kami Reizei family were also out of the capital in the period of the Warring States (Japan), moving to the provinces and into the care of the Hatakeyama clan, the Military Governors of Noto, and the Imagawa clan, the Military Governors of Suruga.

sen.j: 織田信長の時代には都に戻ったが、豊臣秀吉が関白太政大臣に任命された天正13年（1586年）に勅勘を蒙り、再び地方に下った。
sen.e: In the era of Nobunaga ODA, the family went back to the capital; however, the family was punished by Imperial order in 1586, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI was appointed to the Kanpaku Dajodaijin (imperial regent and grand minister), and the family went down to the local areas again.

In the era of Nobunaga ODA, the family returned to the capital, but in 1586, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI was appointed Kanpaku Dajodaijin (imperial regent and grand minister), was punished by Imperial order and sent to the provinces again.

In the era of Nobunaga ODA, the family returned to the capital, but in 1586, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI was appointed Kanpaku Dajodaijin (imperial regent and grand minister), was punished by Imperial order and sent back to the provinces.
sen.cmt: 文体。sent to the provinces again. より sent back to the provincesの方が自然。

sen.j: 秀吉が亡くなった慶長3年（1598年）に徳川家康のとりなしによって、ようやく都へ戻ることができたという。
sen.e: In 1598, when Hideyoshi passed away, the family was able to go back to the capital thanks to the Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's mediation.
When Hideyoshi died in 1598, the family was able to return to the capital thanks to intervention of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
When Hideyoshi died in 1598, the family was able to return to the capital thanks to the intervention of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 文法。「家康の」とりなし、なので定冠詞が必要。

sen.j: かつて秀吉は、天皇の住まう御所周辺に公家たちの屋敷を集め公家町を形成したが、上冷泉家は、公家町が完全に成立した後に許されて都に戻ったため、公家町内に屋敷を構えることが出来なかった。
sen.e: Hideyoshi once gathered residences of court nobilities near the Imperial Palace where the Emperor lived and built a town of court nobilities; however, the Kami Reizei family was unable to have their residence in the town as the family was forgiven and went back to the capital after the town had established completely.

Hideyoshi had gathered residences of the court nobility in a town of court nobility near the Imperial Palace inhabited by Emperor, but the Kami Reizei family were unable to have a residence there because the town had already been fully established by the time they were forgiven and allowed to return.

Hideyoshi had gathered residences of the court nobility in a town of court nobility near the Imperial Palace inhabited by Emperor, but the Kami Reizei family were unable to have a residence there because the town had already been fully established by the time they were forgiven and allowed to return.

sen.j: 旧公家町に隣接した現在の敷地は、家康から贈られたものである。
sen.e: The current site of their residence next to the old town of court nobilities was given by Ieyasu.
The current site of their residence, next to the old town of court nobility, was given to them by Ieyasu.
The current site of their residence, next to the old town of court nobility, was given to them by Ieyasu.

sen.j: 徳川家には厚遇されたので上冷泉家の江戸時代の繁栄ぶりは周知の通りである。
sen.e: As the family was treated very well by the Tokugawa family, they were prosperous during the Edo Period as everyone knows now.
The family was treated very well by the Tokugawa family, and, as is well known, became prosperous during the Edo Period.
The family was treated very well by the Tokugawa family, and, as is well known, became prosperous during the Edo Period.

sen.j: 仙台伊達氏と姻戚でもあった。
sen.e: The family were also related to the Date clan in Sendai.
The family were also related to the Date clan in Sendai.
The family were also related to the Date clan in Sendai.

tit.e: After the Meiji Period
The Meiji Period and beyond
The Meiji Period and beyond

sen.j: 明治時代に、上冷泉家は伯爵、下冷泉家は子爵となった。
sen.e: In the Meiji Period, the Kami Reizei family became the count and the Shimo Reizei family became the viscount.
In the Meiji Period, the Kami Reizei family were awarded the title of count and the Shimo Reizei family were awarded the title of viscount.
In the Meiji Period, the Kami Reizei family were awarded the title of count and the Shimo Reizei family were awarded the title of viscount.

sen.j: 下冷泉家も、家系的には全く劣るものではなかったが、戦国時代に別所氏によって当主が殺され、所領を失ったことが後々官位にも響き、明治期の爵位の差となった。
sen.e: The Shimo Reizei family was not inferior at all in terms of its ancestry; however, the murder of the family head by the Bessho clan and the loss of its domain in the period of Warring States influenced the official rank later and created the difference of titles in the Meiji Period.

This difference in title was not due to any inferiority in terms of ancestry on the part of the Shimo Reizei family; rather, the murder of the family head by the Bessho clan and the loss of land in the period of Warring States subsequently affected their official rank.
sen.cmt: The original sentence is very Japanese in style with the conclusion coming right at the end. In English, it is better switched around, with the conclusion at the beginning.
sen.e: This difference in title was not due to any inferiority in terms of ancestry on the part of the Shimo Reizei family; rather, the murder of the family head by the Bessho clan and the loss of land in the period of Warring States subsequently affected their official rank in the Meiji Period.

sen.j: また、多くの公家は明治天皇に従い東京に移住したが、上冷泉家はその後も京都の江戸時代からの屋敷に住み続けた。
sen.e: Besides, many of court nobilities moved to Tokyo following the Emperor Meiji, but the Kami Reizei family remained to live in the residence in Kyoto where they had been lived since the Edo Period after that.
Many of the court nobility moved to Tokyo after the Meiji Emperor, but the Kami Reizei family remained in Kyoto in the residence they had lived in since the Edo Period.
sen.cmt: With "Emporer Meiji", it sounds like "Meiji" is the Emperor's name. This woul be better as the "Meiji Emperor"
sen.e: Many of the court nobility moved to Tokyo after the Meiji Emperor, but the Kami Reizei family remained in Kyoto in the residence they had lived in since the Edo Period.

sen.j: 現在の京都御苑にあった公家町の公家の屋敷は明治初期の東京移住命令により全て取り壊されたが、今出川以北にあった上冷泉家は取り壊しをまぬがれたといわれている。
sen.e: All of the residences of court nobilities in the town of court nobilities located in the current Kyoto Gyoen were demolished due to the order of relocation to Tokyo announced in the beginning of the Meiji Period; however, it is said that the residence of the Kami Reizei family escaped demolition because they were located above Imadegawa.

The residences in the town of court nobility, located in what is now Kyoto Gyoen, were all demolished on an order of relocation to Tokyo issued at the beginning of the Meiji Period, but the residence of the Kami Reizei family is said to have escaped demolition due to its location to the North of Imadegawa.

The residences in the town of court nobility, located in what is now Kyoto Gyoen, were all demolished on an order of relocation to Tokyo issued at the beginning of the Meiji Period, but the residence of the Kami Reizei family is said to have escaped demolition due to its location to the North of Imadegawa.

sen.j: 一方の下冷泉家は現在の京都迎賓館付近になる京都御苑内に屋敷があったため、取り壊され公園化された。
sen.e: In contrast, the residence of the Shimo Reizei family was located around the current Kyoto State Guest House inside Kyoto Gyoen so that it was demolished and arranged as the garden.
The residence of the Shimo Reizei family, on the other hand, was located near what is now the Kyoto State Guest House inside Kyoto Gyoen, and was consequently demolished to make way for the park.
The residence of the Shimo Reizei family, on the other hand, was located near what is now the Kyoto State Guest House inside Kyoto Gyoen, and was consequently demolished to make way for the park.

sen.j: 太平洋戦争で京都市は戦場になることはなかったが上冷泉家の冷泉為臣（22代当主・冷泉為系の長男）は中国へ出征し、戦死した。
sen.e: Although Kyoto City did not become a battlefield during the Pacific War, Tameomi REIZEI of the Kami Reizei family (the 22nd family head, the first son of Tametsugi REIZEI) went to China and died in battle.

While Kyoto City was not directly attacked during the Pacific War, the Kami Reizei family lost Tameomi REIZEI (the 22nd family head and first son of Tametsugi REIZEI), who died on the battlefield in China.

While Kyoto City was not directly attacked during the Pacific War, the Kami Reizei family lost Tameomi REIZEI (the twenty-second family head and first son of Tametsugi REIZEI), who died on the battlefield in China.

sen.j: 上冷泉家の第25代当主（現当主）冷泉為人は、財団法人冷泉家時雨亭文庫を設立した第24代当主冷泉為任の娘婿で、同文庫の理事長である。
sen.e: Tamehito REIZEI, the 25th family head (the current head) of the Kami Reizei family, is the husband of the daughter of Tametou REIZEI, the 24th family head who established Reizei Shigure-tei Library Foundation, and is the head director of the foundation.

Tametou REIZEI, the 24th family head, established the Reizei Shigure-tei Library Foundation, and Tamehito REIZEI, who married Tametou's daughter and became the 25th (and current) head of the Kami Reizei family, is now the head director of this organization.
sen.cmt: The original translation is confusing. The meaning comes through more clearly when the sentence is rearranged like this.
sen.e: Tameto REIZEI, the twenty-fourth family head, established the Reizei Shigure-tei Library Foundation, and Tamehito REIZEI, who married Tameto's daughter and became the twenty-fifth (and current) head of the Kami Reizei family, is now the head director of this organization.
sen.cmt: 為任＝Tameto, 24代、25代の表記を変更しました。

sen.j: 為人は、近世京都画壇研究の第一人者で、大手前女子大学教授・池坊短期大学学長を経て、現在同志社女子大学客員教授を務めている。
sen.e: Tamehito is a leading expert of the study of Kyoto modern painters, and currently is a guest professor of Doshisha Women's College after he served as the professor of Otemae Women's University and the president of Ikenobo College.

Tamehito is a leading expert in modern Kyoto painters, and is currently a guest professor of Doshisha Women's College, having also held a chair at Otemae Women's University and served as the president of Ikenobo College.

Tamehito is a leading expert in modern Kyoto painters, and is currently a guest professor of Doshisha Women's College, having also held a chair at Otemae Women's University and served as the president of Ikenobo College.

sen.j: 旧姓名は松尾勝彦であったが、為任長女冷泉貴実子の婿として第25代当主を継承するために、家裁手続きを経て現姓名に改めた。
sen.e: His original name was Katsuhiko MATSUO; however, he changed his name through procedures of family court in order to inherit the 25th family head as the husband of Kimiko REIZEI, the daughter of Tameto.
Tamehito used to be called Katsuhiko MATSUO but, on marrying Kimiko REIZEI, Tameto's daughter, changed his name through the family courts to become the 25th head of the Reizei family.
Tamehito was originally called Katsuhiko MATSUO but, on marrying Kimiko REIZEI, Tameto's daughter, changed his name through the family courts to become the twenty-fifth head of the Reizei family.
sen.cmt: 表現として 'was originally' がより適当。

sen.j: 貴実子夫人は、同文庫事務局長である。
sen.e: Madame Kimiko is the Secretary General.
Madame Kimiko is the Secretary General in the same organization
Madame Kimiko is the Secretary General in the same organization

tit.e: Renshi (relatives of noble families)
Renshi (relatives of noble families)
Renshi (relatives of noble families)

sen.j: 入江家
sen.e: The Irie family
The Irie family
The Irie family

sen.j: 藤原定家の血筋を現在まで伝える家に入江家がある。
sen.e: The Irie family is one of the families directly descended from the Fujiwara family
sen.cmt: Not translated. The translation here is mine
sen.e: The Irie family is one of the families directly descended from Sadaie FUJIWARA.

sen.j: 入江家は、天皇に伴い維新後東京に移り、入江為守が東宮侍従長として大正天皇に、また、入江相政が侍従長として昭和天皇にと、天皇家に近侍した。
sen.e: The Irie family moved to Tokyo following the Emperor after the Restoration, and Tamemori IRIE valeted the Emperor Taisho as the grand chamberlain of Crown Prince and Sukemasa IRIE the Emperor Showa as the grand chamberlain.

The Irie family moved to Tokyo with the Emperor after the Restoration, and Tamemori IRIE became valet to the Emperor Taisho, holding the position of grand chamberlain of the Crown Prince, while Sukemasa IRIE became valet to the Emperor Showa, holding the position of grand chamberlain.

The Irie family moved to Tokyo with the Emperor after the Restoration, and Tamemori IRIE became valet to the Emperor Taisho, holding the position of grand chamberlain of the Crown Prince, while Sukemasa IRIE became valet to the Emperor Showa, holding the position of grand chamberlain.

sen.j: 藤谷家
sen.e: The Fujigayatsu family
The Fujigayatsu family
The Fujigayatsu family

sen.j: 藤谷家も一門であるが、阪神大震災で最後の当主が亡くなり、絶家した。
sen.e: The Fujigayatsu family was also a clan, but the family ended because of the death of the last family head in the Great Hanshin Earthquake.
The Fujigayatsu family was also a clan, but the family line ended with the death of the last head of the family in the Great Hanshin Earthquake.
The Fujigayatsu family was also a clan, but the family line ended with the death of the last head of the family in the Great Hanshin Earthquake.

sen.j: 家名の由来は冷泉家の始祖である冷泉為相が鎌倉幕府と親しく、鎌倉の藤ヶ谷に長らく住したことによる。
sen.e: The name of the family came from long living of Tamesuke REIZEI at Fujigayatsu in Kamakura as he had a close relationship with the Kamakura Shogunate.
The family name originated with Tamesuke REIZEI, the founding member of the REIZEI family, who was close to the Kamakura Shogunate and lived a long life at Fujigayatsu in Kamakura.
The family name originated with Tamesuke REIZEI, the founding member of the REIZEI family, who was close to the Kamakura bakufu and lived a long life at Fujigayatsu in Kamakura.

sen.j: 冷泉為相は藤谷為相とも称した。
sen.e: Tamesuke REIZEI also identified himself as Tamesuke FUJIGAYATSU.
Tamesuke REIZEI also identified himself as Tamesuke FUJIGAYATSU.
Tamesuke REIZEI was also called Tamesuke FUJIGAYATSU.

tit.j: 重要文化財・冷泉家住宅
tit.e: Important Cultural Properties, the residence of the House of Reizei
Important Cultural Properties, the residence of the Reizei family
tit.cmt: OK, I think, but thus far, 「冷泉家」 has been translated as the Reizei family, not the House of Reizei
tit.e: Important Cultural Properties, the residence of the Reizei family

sen.j: 上冷泉家住宅は、京都市今出川通烏丸東入ルにあり、重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The residence of the Kami Reizei family is located in Higashi-iru, Karasuma, Imadegawa-dori Street, Kyoto City, and is designated as an important cultural property.
The residence of the Kami Reizei family is located at Karasuma Higashi-iru, Imadegawa-dori Street, Kyoto City, and has been designated an important cultural property.
sen.cmt: I have a feeling that "Karasuma" and "Higashi-iru" should go together…
sen.e: The residence of the Kami Reizei family is located at Karasuma Higashi-iru, Imadegawa-dori Street, Kyoto City, and has been designated an important cultural property.

sen.j: 寛政2年（1790年）の建築で、現存する最古の公家住宅である。
sen.e: The residence was built in 1790 and is the oldest residence of court nobilities now existing.
Built in 1790, the residence is the oldest residence of court nobility still in existence.
Built in 1790, the residence is the oldest residence of court nobility still in existence.

sen.j: 明治時代に、ほとんどの公家は天皇に従って東京に移ったため、現在の京都御苑内にあった殆んどの公家住宅が空家となり治安維持のため取り壊された。
sen.e: Most of the court nobilities moved to Tokyo following the Emperor in the Meiji Period so that their residences located in the current Kyoto Gyoen became vacant, and they were demolished to maintain security.
Since most of the court nobility moved to Tokyo after the Emperor in the Meiji Period, their residences in what is now Kyoto Gyoen became vacant and were demolished to maintain security.
Since most of the court nobility moved to Tokyo after the Emperor in the Meiji Period, their residences in what is now Kyoto Gyoen became vacant and were demolished to maintain security.

sen.j: しかし、上冷泉家には御文庫といわれる、かつては勅封だった蔵もあり、京都御苑外に立地していたため取り壊しも免れた。
sen.e: However, because the Kami Reizei family had Gobunko, a library once locked with Chokufu, imperial seal, and was located outside Kyoto Gyoen, their residence escaped demolition.
However, because the Kami Reizei family had Gobunko, a library at one time locked with Chokufu, the imperial seal, and located outside Kyoto Gyoen, their residence escaped demolition.
However, because the Kami Reizei family had Gobunko, a library at one time locked with Chokufu, the imperial seal, and located outside Kyoto Gyoen, their residence escaped demolition.

sen.j: 御文庫を擁する上冷泉家が関西の京都に残ったことで、結果として膨大な至宝が関東大震災と東京大空襲から守り抜かれたことは、日本文化史上この上ない僥倖である。
sen.e: It is an ultimate sheer chance in the Japanese cultural history that enormous great treasures were eventually safe from the Great Kanto Earthquake and Great Tokyo Air Raids as the Kami Reizei family which holds Gobunko remained in Kyoto in Kansai.

It is a happy accident of Japanese cultural history that the Kami Reizei family which holds Gobunko remained in Kyoto in Kansai, keeping these great treasures safe from the Great Kanto Earthquake and the bombing of Tokyo.

It is a happy accident of Japanese cultural history that the Kami Reizei family which holds Gobunko remained in Kyoto in Kansai, keeping these great treasures safe from the Great Kanto Earthquake and the bombing of Tokyo.

tit.j: 京都御苑および周辺に残るその他の公家住宅
tit.e: Other residences of court nobilities remaining in and around Kyoto Gyoen
Other remaining court nobility residences in and around Kyoto Gyoen
Other remaining court nobility residences in and around Kyoto Gyoen

sen.j: 二条城 - 京都御苑内には築地と門のみ残り、建物は二条城内に移築。
sen.e: Nijo Castle - Only the wall and gate are left in Kyoto Gyoen, and the building is removed and rebuilt inside Nijo Castle.
sen.cmt: 「二条城・・・建物は二条城内に移築」原文がおかしいように思います。最初の「二条城」の部分が別の固有名詞なのではないでしょうか？
sen.e: Nijo Castle - One residence formerly located in Kyoto Gyoen was moved and rebuilt in the grounds of Nijo Castle, leaving only a wall and gate in the original location.
sen.cmt: I agree that the source text is a little strange, but I think the meaning might be along these lines.
sen.e: Nijo-jo Castle - One residence formerly located in Kyoto Gyoen was moved and rebuilt in the grounds of Nijo-jo Castle, leaving only a wall and gate in the original location.
sen.cmt: 原文「二条城・・・建物は二条城内に移築」の最初の「二条城」の部分は別の固有名詞なのではないでしょうか？ 二条城＝Nijo-jo Castleに。

sen.j: 閑院宮 - 京都御苑内に残る唯一の公家住宅。
sen.e: Kanin-gu - The only residence of court nobility left inside Kyoto Gyoen.
Kanin-gu - The only residence of the court nobility left inside Kyoto Gyoen.
Kanin-gu - The only residence of the court nobility left inside Kyoto Gyoen.
